posts.name: Jpaulbiss
posts.cooked: I was under the impression that signal was a Swiss firm. Wikipedia claims it is US based.

usa!

and i wonder where you get this erroneous information?
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Jpaulbiss
posts.cooked:
en.wikipedia.org

Signal (software)

Signal is an American open-source, encrypted messaging service for instant messaging, voice calls, and video calls. The instant messaging function includes sending text, voice notes, images, videos, and other files. Communication may be one-to-one between users or may involve group messaging. The application uses a centralized computing architecture and is cross-platform software. It is developed by the non-profit Signal Technology Foundation and its subsidiary Signal Messenger LLC. Signal's s...

You might be thinking of Threema:

GitHub

Threema GmbH

Seriously Secure Messaging. Impressum: threema.ch/impressum - Threema GmbH

It is somewhat similar to Signal and based in Switzerland.

posts.cooked: Signal has always been based in the U.S. The app is owned by an American charity.
you might be thinking of Proton Mail, they‚Äôre swiss based

posts.name: Jpaulbiss
posts.cooked: I do not know where I came to the conclusion that it was Swiss, wishful thinking maybe. I just wonder how secure it will be in the furure, since that the Video Idiocracy has become a real life drama.

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked:
jpaulbiss:

I just wonder how secure it will be in the furure,

You haven‚Äôt been the first, you‚Äôre never going to be the last ‚Äî as much as that is wishful thinking ‚Äî and Signal will keep on moving.

If Signal were from Swiss,
‚Ä¶ it would cost money
Not necessarily, Threema is also free and quite similar. But it is probably more expensive to run your servers in Switzerland than in the US, so they possibly require more donations to stay alive.

desert_nip:

Threema is also free

Threema is not cost free. The app requires a one time fee.
Oups, sorry, you‚Äôre absolutely right, I forgot about that. I‚Äôve never used Threema and had only looked at the GitHub page.

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked:
desert_nip:

I‚Äôve never used Threema and had only looked at the GutHub page.

I seriously feel for website designers sometimes, haha.

With that being said, I checked the Threema webpage for the first time in awhile, and, man, they‚Äôre far more arrogant and high horsed than I remembered with little to justify it. It‚Äôs especially amusing considering how much they try and present with ‚Äújust download and go‚Äù while barely being upfront with that fact that a gate will trip you immediately.

posts.name: Jpaulbiss
posts.cooked: Every month my wife and I donate money to Signal for its‚Äô use. Not really free if value their service.

posts.name: Jpaulbiss
posts.cooked:
Probably, the wages are better. Minimum wage is Switzerland is between $4000 & $5000 a month. Then there is 6 weeks paid holiday a year, free healthcare, dental, sometimes a 13th month pay cheque, free post secondary education.
It adds to the cost.

posts.name: Jpaulbiss
posts.cooked: My aside was about the future of data security. Signal uses infrastructure from Amazon Web Services, Google Compute Engine and Microsoft Azure. Their owners are friend of the present US regime. Would Signals data be turned over is asked?

jpaulbiss:

Would Signals data be turned over is asked?

The benefit of Signal is that there is little data to turn over. Signal does comply with every legal subpoena, but the relinquished data is only that there is an account, the timestamp of account creation, and the timestamp of the last time the account was accessed.

jpaulbiss:

Every month my wife and I donate money to Signal for its‚Äô use. Not really free if value their service.

It‚Äôs wonderful, that you two donate. But you know the meaning of donation and the difference between a donation and a price.

Signal is free. Threema costs about 5 $ or so.

posts.name: Jpaulbiss
posts.cooked: At least it is not like Google where you get ads based on the content of you last email, or the location of your phone yesterday. I installed e/OS on our Android phones 2 years ago, all those friendly ads stopped

CueHD:

Signal does comply with every legal subpoena

I feel one thing needs to be said plainly to avoid any misconceptions: Signal does comply with every legal subpoena like any other entity who wants keep existing.

No matter whether they based in US or Switzerland. For example Swiss based Proton never concealed fact that while they won‚Äôt respond to any foreign law enforcement demands just because someone demands information, they‚Äôll always comply with Swiss subpoenas (including from foreign countries if they asked for the info via proper Swiss judicial channels) because the law mandates such compliance. I don‚Äôt think anything changed in the matter.
